page.title: 04Railways 1862-1985 Part 1
page.content: In 1862, the London & North Western Railway opened an extension of their Bletchley to Bedford line via Sandy to Cambridge, using Captain Peel's railway. A branch from Sandy had been proposed by the G.N.R. in 1850 to run to Bedford but opposition from other railway companies forced them to abandon the idea. When it did open, it became well- known as the 'Universities Line,' running as it did from Cambridge with a connection at Bletchley on to Oxford. The countryside through which it passed was very lightly populated and therefore, although it carried some local market gardening produce, it was not used by large numbers of passengers.
